intro: Glycine dilecta, commonly known as the white clover, is a flowering plant belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa, and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small white or pink flowers. The plant is known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen through symbiotic relationships with Rhizobium bacteria in its root nodules. Glycine dilecta thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in lawns, meadows, and pastures. It plays an important ecological role by improving soil fertility and serving as a food source for various insects and animals.
